attributes.title: Impact of COVID-19 exposure on punishment responsiveness
attributes.description: We investigate whether COVID-19 exposure changes participants’ threat-detection threshold. Sensitivity to threat was measured in a signal detection task among 397 British adults who also reported how much vulnerable they felt to infectious disease. Participants’ data were then matched to the number of confirmed COVID-19 collected from the NHS database. We found that participants who perceive themselves as more likely to catch infectious diseases displayed a higher negativity bias in response to increased COVID-19 cases. In addition, we found a significant effect of education on participants’ punishment responsiveness in response to COVID-19 exposure. A second wave of data collection is planned exactly two weeks after the first one. The goal of this second wave is to replicate the findings and document the impact of increasing COVID-19 cases and deaths on people’s psychology.

attributes.title: Stigma toward Trump/Republicans
attributes.description: Project on Stigma, Political Orientation, Perceived (In)Tolerance

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value: We have no effect size information on which to base power analyses. We aim to collect 300 usable Ps for this first exploration of our hypotheses.

analyses.value:
-Regression predicting stigma from condition, political orientation (centered) and the interaction term.
-Regression predicting intolerance of historically marginalized groups from condition, political orientation (centered) and the interaction term 
[-Regression predicting intolerance of other groups from condition, political orientation (centered) and the interaction term] (Supplement to explore within-subjects factor with ANOVA)
- PROCESS to explore mediation and predicted moderated mediation

outliers.value: We will use bot (same two same-sex friends) and attention checks (e.g., write the correct term in the text box), excluding Ps failing those.

dependent.value:
a. Participants will rate how tolerant and supportive the target is of certain groups (e.g., Racial/Ethnic minorities, Trans people, People with traditional family values).
b. Participants will rank how accurate each statement about target and his association with specific groups (e.g., Black Lives Matter, Blue Lives Matter), adapted from Perceptions of Value Violation (Mather & Tranby 2014, Wethweall, Brandt, & Reyna 2018 ). 
c. Stigma - Participants will rate how much they like and dislike target on a scale from 1 to 7.
d. Stigma - Feeling Thermometer. Participants will rate target on how cold or warm they feel towards him on a sliding scale.

conditions.value:
2 (Target: Trump-supporter, Control)

- We also measure predictor variable Political Orientation via three items assessing social, economic, and overall political orientation, from extremely liberal to extremely conservative, on a sliders set to the midpoint.

hypothesis.value: RQ: Do (some) people stigmatize Trump supporters (vs control) because supporters are perceived as intolerant of historically marginalized groups? H1 We predict that especially liberal people will stigmatize Trump supporters more than a control target. H2 We predict that especially people perceive Trump supporters (vs control) as more intolerant of historically marginalized/lower-power groups (e.g., women, racial/ethnic minorities)--but not as more intolerant of other groups (e.g., NRA members).  H3 We also predict that this perceived intolerance statistically mediates the relationship between target (Trump supporter, control) and stigmatization especially for liberal social perceivers.

attributes.title: Euro CoC Review
attributes.description:
This document represents the registration of the protocol for the review: 'Efforts to improve research quality across disciplines - An analysis of codes of conduct from European learned societies' on 7th April 2020.

The research question, objectives, methods etc. are presented in the following documents:

1) Euro CoC review protocol_07.04.20_Final 
2) AppendixA. Search strategy 3_Final

The aim of the review is to ​analyse how European discipline-specific learned societies conceptualize research integrity and the factors that contribute to good quality research in their codes of conduct (and/or similar documents/statements ​such as position papers, guidelines, etc.). We will do this by assessing the similarities and differences that exist between codes of conduct of European learned societies ​from different disciplines. Additionally, we will assess the correspondence of these codes of conduct with the European Code of Conduct for Research Integrity, with a view to understanding ​how cross-disciplinary efforts to improve research quality correspond to efforts to do the same within disciplines. ​We will use a systematic review of grey and published literature to find the discipline-specific learned societies' codes of conduct, and we will analyze the documents related to research quality and integrity using content analysis.

attributes.title: Socioeconomic position and the effect of kcal labelling and PACE labelling on self-served portion size
attributes.description:
Socio-economic position (SEP) has a key-role in health and several studies have highlighted differences in dietary behaviour between people of lower and higher SEP as potential mediators of this relationship (Giskes et al., 2010; Mackenbach et al., 2019; Pigeyre et al., 2016). It has been shown that people of lower SEP are more likely to behave in ways that increase the likelihood of developing cardiovascular diseases and obesity (e.g., higher consumption of meat and fatty foods, alcohol consumption and smoking) (Adler et al., 1994; Méjean et al., 2013). In developed countries, the prevalence of obesity and other chronic diseases has dramatically increased within all the socio-economic groups (WHO/FAO Expert Consultation, 2003) but to a larger extent among poorer and less educated groups (Burkert et al., 2013). This social gradient might be explained by lower SEP being associated with increased energy intake (Cardel et al., 2016; Sim et al., 2018; Wijayatunga et al., 2019).

Nutritional labelling is one of the most common intervention that has been implemented to reduce energy intake (Crockett et al., 2018). Nutritional labels provide consumers with different types of information (e.g. nutritional composition, energy content) in various ways (e.g. numerical, daily recommended intake, traffic lights) and may have a positive impact on food choices and energy intake (Crockett et al., 2018). However, Sarink et al. (2016) investigated the impact of kcal labelling in people of lower vs. higher SEP and showed that it may benefit more people of higher SEP than people of lower SEP, which may in turn increase health inequalities (Sarink et al., 2016).

A novel form of labelling is Physical Activity Calorie Equivalent (PACE) which may be an alternative to numerical energy labelling (Daley et al., 2019). PACE labelling aims to encourage healthier eating behaviours by providing an interpretation of the energy content of a food in terms of energy expenditure: how many minutes (time) or how many kilometres/miles (distance) of physical activity (e.g. walking, running, swimming, bicycle) are needed to burn off the corresponding energy (Daley et al., 2019). PACE might be easier to understand compared to other nutritional labels because consumers do not need health literacy or have advanced numeracy skills to understand PACE (Reale & Flint, 2016). However, in a recent study, Antonelli & Viera (2015) showed a stronger effect of PACE among people of higher compared to lower SEP, in particular among richer people (Antonelli & Viera, 2015).

The food choices of people of higher SEP are more motivated by health than those of people of lower SEP (Konttinen et al., 2012). As information-based interventions typically rely on people being motivated by health in their food choices (Dubé & Cantin, 2000), the presence of nutritional labels may lead to healthier eating behaviours primarily among people of higher SEP.

Primary objective

To investigate the effect of labelling (kcal or PACE) on the total self-served energy among participants of lower and higher SEP.

Secondary objective

To investigate the psychological processes that may explain the different effect of the intervention and whether health motivation and physical activity level mediate the differential effect of labelling (kcal or PACE) on total self-served energy among participants of lower and higher SEP.

q2.value:
Primary hypotheses

Labelling (kcal or PACE) will influence the size of self-served portion and result in reduced total self-served energy among both participants of lower and higher SEP.

Kcal and PACE labelling will exert a stronger effect on self-served energy among participants of higher compared to lower SEP.

Secondary hypotheses

Participants of higher SEP will have better executive function than participants of lower SEP, which will moderate the relationship between SEP and the effect of energy/PACE labelling on the total energy of the selected meal.

Kcal/PACE labelling will exert a stronger effect on self-served energy among participants of higher SEP because they will be more motivated by health in their food choices than participants of lower SEP.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will take part in an online survey. They will be asked to choose the amount of food they would like to eat based on the pictures of 18 dishes sequentially displayed on the screen. They will be randomly allocated to four different groups: kcal labelling, PACE labelling (minutes to walk to burn off the calories), kcal and PACE labelling combined, no labelling, in a between-subject design.

q7.value: Participants will be equally randomised and allocated to one of the four experimental groups using Inquisit software.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through Prolific, an online recruitment platform in which participants are compensated proportionate to the time it takes to complete the online study (≈ 5£/hour reward participants). Participants’ recruitment will be stratified by gender (50% male, 50% female), student status (3.5% yes and 96.5% no) and qualification levels (50% A level or below, 50% above A level) in order to recruit participants of lower and higher SEP.

Inclusion criteria

•	UK residents, age ≥ 18
•	Fluent in English
•	Have access to a computer and Internet

Exclusion criteria

•	Having any dietary restriction:
o	Vegetarian
o	Vegan
o	Gluten-free
o	Sugar-free
o	Diary/lactose-free
o	Food allergy (e.g. milk, eggs, nut, wheat, fish, etc.)

q11.value:
We will recruit 1,800 participants in total, 450 per intervention group:
o	kcal labelling (kcal+/PACE-)
o	PACE labelling (kcal-/PACE+)
o	kcal and PACE labelling (kcal+/PACE+)
o	no labelling (kcal-/PACE-)

q12.value:
A meta-analysis of six studies investigating the impact of kcal labelling on energy consumed from a single food did not demonstrate a statistically significant effect (Crockett et al., 2018). However the designs of these studies were different from the present study: the food options were mainly snacks (only one study offered to consume main meals (Kral et al., 2002)) and participants were not aware of the amount of kcal they actually consumed (the label was placed on the container or packaging, adjacent to the food, or presented on a display board). In our design, we expect a significant effect of kcal labelling with a reduction of 8.4% of self-served energy per meal may occur, which is the effect size found in a meta-analysis investigating the impact of kcal labelling on energy consumed during a meal with a range of available food options – i.e., the most similar design to the present study. The most up to date evidence of an effect of PACE labelling on energy consumed from foods/drinks is a meta-analysis of two studies and showed a significant reduction of 14.4%. Due to the small number of participants included in this meta-analysis, we conservatory powered our study to be able to detect an 8% reduction for both type of labels (kcal, PACE or kcal and PACE).

We will run a two-level mixed model including 18 trials (level 1) per participant (level 2) and compare self-served energy in each of the four trial arms (control, kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling). We estimate SD of 300 kcal for self-served energy at level 1 and level 2 based on average SD of energy consumed during experimental meals (Crockett et al., 2018). A sample size of 1,600 participants with α = 0.05 will allow to detect a 8% energy reduction between any of the four groups at power = 0.80. It will also allow to detect a small effect (f=0.07) of the interaction between the interventions and higher educational qualification education at power = 0.80 (MLPowSim) (Browne et al., 2009).

In a previous study we conducted at virtual fast food restaurants (Marty et al., 2020), we found small-to-medium correlation between level of education and healthiness motivation (r=0.17) and small-to-medium correlation between healthiness motivation and kcal ordered (r=-0.25). Because evidence of a relationship between SEP and physical activity is mixed (Gidlow et al., 2006), we hypothesize small-to-medium correlation. Empirical estimates of sample sizes needed for 0.8 power in mediation analyses indicate that samples of ≈ 380 are sufficient to detect mediation through pathways that are small and small-to-medium in statistical size using bias-corrected bootstrap tests (Fritz & Mackinnon, 2007). Thus, a sample of 1,600 participants (i.e., 400 per experimental condition) would allow for adequate power in our planned moderated mediation analysis.

We will recruit a sample of 1,800 participants (who consent to take part in the study) to account for potential data loss due to dropouts and failed quality controls (approx. 10%) resulting in a minimum sample of 1,600 participants for analyses. However, if we experience a greater loss of data than expected, we will continue to recruit participants until we achieve the required sample size of 1,600 participants.

Browne, W. J., Lahi, M. G., & Parker, R. M. a. (2009). International Journal of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity, 17(1), 1–11. https://doi.org/10.1186/s12966-020-0922-2

question.value:
Procedure

Participants will be randomly allocated to one of the following groups:
o	kcal labelling (kcal+/PACE-);
o	PACE labelling (kcal-/PACE+);
o	kcal and PACE labelling (kcal+/PACE+);
o	no labelling (kcal-/PACE-).

They will be asked to choose the amount of food they would like to eat in 18 hypothetical meals sequentially displayed on the screen. The first picture of each dish will show 20 kcal of this dish on a white plate. Participants will be able to virtually ‘serve themselves’ the amount of food they would like to eat by increasing or reducing the quantity on the plate using the arrow keys on their keyboard (to increase = right key; to decrease = left key). Energy content will increase by 20 kcal each time they will tap the right arrow key (max. 1000 kcal). Participants will have to increase the portion size at least once (i.e., at least one tap on the right arrow key) to be able to confirm their choice using the spacebar. The 18 dishes will be randomised in order.

Foods

The food stimuli are based on a previously published work by Whitelock et al. (2018) (Appendix A). For each dish, 50 pictures have been taken to reflect the increase in portion size. The number of calories increases 20 kcal by 20 kcal from a minimum of 20 kcal (first picture) to a maximum of 1000 kcal (50th picture) (Whitelock et al., 2018).

Interventions 

For each portion and dish, participants will see on the screen a label showing the number of calories, physical activity calories equivalent or both. Labels are adapted from Swartz et al., 2013 (Swartz et al., 2013).

Kcal labelling (kcal+/PACE-)
Participants allocated to this group will see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based on how many times they tap on the corresponding keys and a real-time kcal counter synchronised with the food amount changes (i.e., increasing/decreasing).

PACE labelling (kcal-/PACE+)
Participants allocated to this group will see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based on how many times they tap on the corresponding keys and a real-time PACE counter (as minutes needed to walk to burn off the calories) synchronised to the food amount changes (i.e., increasing/decreasing) with 4 min being equivalent to 20 kcal (Daley et al., 2019).

Kcal and PACE labelling (kcal+/PACE+)
Participants allocated to this group will see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based on how many times they tap on the corresponding keys and a real-time kcal and PACE counters synchronised to the food amount changes (i.e., increasing/decreasing).

No labelling (kcal-/PACE-)
Participants allocated to this group will only see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based how many times they tap on the corresponding keys.

Daley, A. J., McGee, E., Bayliss, S., Coombe, A., & Parretti, H. M. (2019). Effects of physical activity calorie equivalent food labelling to reduce food selection and consumption: Systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled studies. Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health, 1–7. https://doi.org/10.1136/jech-2019-213216
Swartz, J. J., Dowray, S., Braxton, D., Mihas, P., & Viera, A. J. (2013). Simplifying healthful choices: A qualitative study of a physical activity based nutrition label format. Nutrition Journal, 12(1), 1–9. https://doi.org/10.1186/1475-2891-12-72
Whitelock, V., Higgs, S., Brunstrom, J. M., Halford, J. C. G., & Robinson, E. (2018). No effect of focused attention whilst eating on later snack food intake: Two laboratory experiments. Appetite, 128(April), 188–196. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2018.06.002

Primary outcome

The main outcome variable is the total self-served energy (in kcal).

Other outcomes:

Derived from the debriefing questionnaire:
1.	Kcal influence (item 1): whether kcal content influences the quantity of self-served food;
2.	PACE influence (item 2): whether physical activity energy equivalent influences the quantity of self-served food.
Answers to each item will be coded as: 1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Slightly disagree; 4 = Neutral; 5 = Slightly agree; 6 = Agree; 7 = Strongly agree.

Independent variables

Highest educational qualification will be coded from 1 to 9: 1 = No formal qualifications; 2 = 1–3 GCSEs; 3 = 4+ GCSEs; 4 = A level; 5 = Certificate of higher education (CertHE); 6 = Diploma of higher education (DipHE); 7 = Bachelor; 8 = Master’s degree; 9 = Doctorate, and as a binary variable as lower (values: 1, 2, 3, 4 ) or higher (values: 5, 6, 7, 8, 9).

Years in higher education, as a continuous variable.

Level of education (composite score): Assuming that highest educational qualification and years in higher education will be significantly correlated (tested using Pearson’s r), we will z-score the two variables and create an average of the two to form a level of education composite score.

Equivalised household income: The OECD-modified equivalence scale will be used to adjust household income considering household size and composition (Office for National Statistics, 2015). Equivalised household income is calculated by dividing the after-tax household (including all the earner to the nearest £1000) by the sum of the equivalence value of all the household members (1 = first adult; 0.5 = additional adult or child >14 years old; 0.3 = child aged 0-13 years old).

Subjective SEP: The measure of the Subjective Social Status using the MacArthur Scale will be coded from 1 (lower SSS) to 10 (higher SSS).

Inhibition – Stroop task: The median reaction times (RTs) will be calculated for correct responses in incongruent and congruent trials. The interference effect will be calculated as the difference between the median RTs of the incongruent trials and the congruent trials. A larger interference score is indicative of poorer inhibition. RTs data are commonly skewed, reflecting lapses of attention or eye blinks during the task (Heathcote et al., 1991). To resolve this, median will be used instead of means. Median is less affected by extreme scores than the mean and provides a better estimate of central tendency for skewed distributions (Ratcliff, 1993; Rousselet & Wilcox, 2019). We will also calculate the proportion of correct responses in incongruent trials because this outcome has been previously linked to the frequency of fatty food consumption (Hall, 2012).

Working memory – backwards digit-span task: The two-error maximum length will be calculated. It is the last digit-span a participant gets correct before making two consecutive errors and the traditional measure of a participant’s backward digit span (Woods et al., 2012). We will also calculate the maximum length i.e., the maximal backward digit span that a participant recalled correctly during all 14 trials.

Familiarity
When the answer to the question “Have you ever eaten this food?” will be ‘yes’, the food will be coded as familiar for a participant.

Liking
For each participant and each food a liking score from 0 to 100 will be recorded (anchors: not at all, extremely).

Health motivation in food choices
Health and weight control motivation scores will be computed by averaging ratings for individual items in each dimension (health motivation: 6 items; weight control motivation: 4 items). They will range from 1 to 4: 1 = Not at all important; 2 = A little important; 3 = Moderately important; 4 = Very important.

Other variables

BMI will be calculated as weight (kg) / height (m2). BMI data will be trimmed for implausible values excluding weight for less than 30 kg and more than 250 kg, height for less than 145 cm and more than 3m, BMI < 14 or BMI > 48 (Hardy et al., 2016; Miller, 2003).

Physical activity level will be estimated based on IPAQ-SF answers as MET-minutes per week : self-reported physical activity in minutes*MET score [walking = 3.3, moderate intensity = 4.0, vigorous intensity = 8.0]*number of days (Craig et al., 2003).

Aim guessing: Participants who identify the aim of the study as being to examine the influence of kcal or PACE labelling on self-served food portion size will be coded as being aware of the study aims. Responses will be independently coded by two researchers, with discrepancies in coding decisions resolved by a third researcher.

Main analyses

The primary aim of the statistical analyses will be to test the effect the labelling intervention and SEP on self-served energy. Secondary analyses will be run in order to investigate the role of potential mediators to explain the relationship SEP-self-served energy. The measure of SEP used in our main analyses will be the highest educational qualification (binary variable: lower vs. higher) because previous research showed that people of higher education were more likely to use nutrition labels (Breck et al., 2014; Cowburn & Stockley, 2008).

Linear mixed effect models will be run in order to test the effect of the labels and of highest educational qualification on the self-served energy, with participants and dishes set as random effects to account for correlation between repeated measures by the same participant and across the different food items. The main model will test the effect of the labelling intervention (four levels: kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling, no labelling), highest educational qualification (two levels: lower, higher) and the interaction between labelling intervention and highest educational qualification. If the interaction is significant, analyses will be stratified by highest educational qualification (lower and higher) and two linear mixed models will be fitted to examine the effect of the labelling intervention on self-served energy.

If there is a main effect of the labelling intervention in one of the above linear mixed models we will follow up this main effect by conducting the following pairwise comparisons:

-	Self-served energy in each of the three labelling conditions compared to no labelling condition:
o	No labelling vs. kcal labelling
o	No labelling vs. PACE labelling
o	No labelling vs. kcal and PACE labelling combined

-	Self-served energy in the combined labelling condition compared to single labelling conditions
o	Kcal and PACE labelling combined vs. kcal labelling
o	Kcal and PACE labelling combined vs. PACE labelling

-	Self-served energy in one single labelling condition compared to the other single labelling condition:
o	Kcal labelling vs. PACE labelling

We will apply a Bonferroni correction to the level of significance based on the number of pairwise comparisons made (e.g., 12 comparisons: 0.05/12=0.004).

Sensitivity analyses

We will conduct sensitivity analyses to examine whether the pattern of results from the main analyses differ when:

-	excluding the aim guessers from the main analyses, or if more than 20% of participants guess the aim of the study, including an ‘aim guessing’ variable (two levels: yes, no) as a covariate in the main model;

-	substituting highest educational qualification by level of education (composite score) in the main model;

-	including hunger and liking as covariates in the main model as these two variables are likely to influence how much one serves oneself of a dish;

-	excluding any dish that is familiar to less than 50% of participants or that is scored < 50 in liking on average (mid-way of the scale) to examine whether results are consistent when only well liked and familiar foods are used.

We will report whether sensitivity analyses result in deviations from the pattern of significance to the main analyses (i.e., any significant differences between conditions becoming not significant, and vice versa).

Secondary analyses

The main analyses will be repeated using alternative measures of SEP to investigate whether different measures lead to the same pattern of results. Highest educational qualification will be substituted by 1/ equivalised income, and 2/ SSS.

Moderated mediation analyses

We will report and compare the measures of inhibition, working memory, healthiness and weight control motivation in food choices overall and for participants of lower vs. higher education level using means, standard deviations and t-tests.

If the main analyses suggest that highest educational qualification moderates the effect of labelling intervention (i.e., the labelling intervention*highest educational qualification is significant), moderated mediation analyses will be performed in order to explain the different effect of labelling intervention in participants of lower vs. higher education level. We will test as mediators the measures of inhibition, working memory, healthiness and weight control motivation in food choices only if we find individual differences on these measures between participants of lower and higher education level. Moderated mediation analyses will examine the extent to which they mediate the effect of highest educational qualification on self-served energy in each labelling condition (kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling, no labelling).

The moderated mediation will be tested by estimating the conditional indirect effect of highest educational qualification through M for kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling, no labelling conditions and testing the conditional indirect effect for those conditions using bias-corrected bootstrap. We will use the PROCESS macro (Model 15) on SAS version 9.3 that provides asymmetric bias-corrected bootstrap confidence intervals for inference about the conditional indirect effects using 5,000 bootstrap samples (Hayes, 2012). Moderated mediation will be tested by determining whether or not the confidence interval for the difference between conditional indirect effects for kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling versus no labelling contains zero.

q22.value:
Analysis of potential moderators of the effect of the labelling intervention

We will explore if the other variables we will measure could individually moderate the effect of the labelling intervention on self-served energy independently of SEP. We will substitute highest educational qualification in the main analyses by measures of inhibition, working memory, healthiness and weight control motivation in food choices, physical activity in MET-minutes for walking and in total.

Debriefing questionnaire

Answers to all the items of the debriefing questionnaire will be described as mean ± SD overall and for participants of lower and higher education. Differences between the two groups will be tested using t-tests. Two ANOVAs will be run to test the effect of the labelling intervention and of highest educational qualification on the first two items: kcal influence and PACE influence.

registration_responses.q2:
Primary hypotheses

Labelling (kcal or PACE) will influence the size of self-served portion and result in reduced total self-served energy among both participants of lower and higher SEP.

Kcal and PACE labelling will exert a stronger effect on self-served energy among participants of higher compared to lower SEP.

Secondary hypotheses

Participants of higher SEP will have better executive function than participants of lower SEP, which will moderate the relationship between SEP and the effect of energy/PACE labelling on the total energy of the selected meal.

Kcal/PACE labelling will exert a stronger effect on self-served energy among participants of higher SEP because they will be more motivated by health in their food choices than participants of lower SEP.

registration_responses.q12:
A meta-analysis of six studies investigating the impact of kcal labelling on energy consumed from a single food did not demonstrate a statistically significant effect (Crockett et al., 2018). However the designs of these studies were different from the present study: the food options were mainly snacks (only one study offered to consume main meals (Kral et al., 2002)) and participants were not aware of the amount of kcal they actually consumed (the label was placed on the container or packaging, adjacent to the food, or presented on a display board). In our design, we expect a significant effect of kcal labelling with a reduction of 8.4% of self-served energy per meal may occur, which is the effect size found in a meta-analysis investigating the impact of kcal labelling on energy consumed during a meal with a range of available food options – i.e., the most similar design to the present study. The most up to date evidence of an effect of PACE labelling on energy consumed from foods/drinks is a meta-analysis of two studies and showed a significant reduction of 14.4%. Due to the small number of participants included in this meta-analysis, we conservatory powered our study to be able to detect an 8% reduction for both type of labels (kcal, PACE or kcal and PACE).

We will run a two-level mixed model including 18 trials (level 1) per participant (level 2) and compare self-served energy in each of the four trial arms (control, kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling). We estimate SD of 300 kcal for self-served energy at level 1 and level 2 based on average SD of energy consumed during experimental meals (Crockett et al., 2018). A sample size of 1,600 participants with α = 0.05 will allow to detect a 8% energy reduction between any of the four groups at power = 0.80. It will also allow to detect a small effect (f=0.07) of the interaction between the interventions and higher educational qualification education at power = 0.80 (MLPowSim) (Browne et al., 2009).

In a previous study we conducted at virtual fast food restaurants (Marty et al., 2020), we found small-to-medium correlation between level of education and healthiness motivation (r=0.17) and small-to-medium correlation between healthiness motivation and kcal ordered (r=-0.25). Because evidence of a relationship between SEP and physical activity is mixed (Gidlow et al., 2006), we hypothesize small-to-medium correlation. Empirical estimates of sample sizes needed for 0.8 power in mediation analyses indicate that samples of ≈ 380 are sufficient to detect mediation through pathways that are small and small-to-medium in statistical size using bias-corrected bootstrap tests (Fritz & Mackinnon, 2007). Thus, a sample of 1,600 participants (i.e., 400 per experimental condition) would allow for adequate power in our planned moderated mediation analysis.

We will recruit a sample of 1,800 participants (who consent to take part in the study) to account for potential data loss due to dropouts and failed quality controls (approx. 10%) resulting in a minimum sample of 1,600 participants for analyses. However, if we experience a greater loss of data than expected, we will continue to recruit participants until we achieve the required sample size of 1,600 participants.

registration_responses.q6.question: Participants will take part in an online survey. They will be asked to choose the amount of food they would like to eat based on the pictures of 18 dishes sequentially displayed on the screen. They will be randomly allocated to four different groups: kcal labelling, PACE labelling (minutes to walk to burn off the calories), kcal and PACE labelling combined, no labelling, in a between-subject design.
registration_responses.q10.question:
Participants will be recruited through Prolific, an online recruitment platform in which participants are compensated proportionate to the time it takes to complete the online study (≈ 5£/hour reward participants). Participants’ recruitment will be stratified by gender (50% male, 50% female), student status (3.5% yes and 96.5% no) and qualification levels (50% A level or below, 50% above A level) in order to recruit participants of lower and higher SEP.

Inclusion criteria

•	UK residents, age ≥ 18
•	Fluent in English
•	Have access to a computer and Internet

Exclusion criteria

•	Having any dietary restriction:
o	Vegetarian
o	Vegan
o	Gluten-free
o	Sugar-free
o	Diary/lactose-free
o	Food allergy (e.g. milk, eggs, nut, wheat, fish, etc.)
registration_responses.q14.question:
Procedure

Participants will be randomly allocated to one of the following groups:
o	kcal labelling (kcal+/PACE-);
o	PACE labelling (kcal-/PACE+);
o	kcal and PACE labelling (kcal+/PACE+);
o	no labelling (kcal-/PACE-).

They will be asked to choose the amount of food they would like to eat in 18 hypothetical meals sequentially displayed on the screen. The first picture of each dish will show 20 kcal of this dish on a white plate. Participants will be able to virtually ‘serve themselves’ the amount of food they would like to eat by increasing or reducing the quantity on the plate using the arrow keys on their keyboard (to increase = right key; to decrease = left key). Energy content will increase by 20 kcal each time they will tap the right arrow key (max. 1000 kcal). Participants will have to increase the portion size at least once (i.e., at least one tap on the right arrow key) to be able to confirm their choice using the spacebar. The 18 dishes will be randomised in order.

Foods

The food stimuli are based on a previously published work by Whitelock et al. (2018) (Appendix A). For each dish, 50 pictures have been taken to reflect the increase in portion size. The number of calories increases 20 kcal by 20 kcal from a minimum of 20 kcal (first picture) to a maximum of 1000 kcal (50th picture) (Whitelock et al., 2018).

Interventions 

For each portion and dish, participants will see on the screen a label showing the number of calories, physical activity calories equivalent or both. Labels are adapted from Swartz et al., 2013 (Swartz et al., 2013).

Kcal labelling (kcal+/PACE-)
Participants allocated to this group will see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based on how many times they tap on the corresponding keys and a real-time kcal counter synchronised with the food amount changes (i.e., increasing/decreasing).

PACE labelling (kcal-/PACE+)
Participants allocated to this group will see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based on how many times they tap on the corresponding keys and a real-time PACE counter (as minutes needed to walk to burn off the calories) synchronised to the food amount changes (i.e., increasing/decreasing) with 4 min being equivalent to 20 kcal (Daley et al., 2019).

Kcal and PACE labelling (kcal+/PACE+)
Participants allocated to this group will see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based on how many times they tap on the corresponding keys and a real-time kcal and PACE counters synchronised to the food amount changes (i.e., increasing/decreasing).

No labelling (kcal-/PACE-)
Participants allocated to this group will only see on the screen the amount of food increasing or decreasing based how many times they tap on the corresponding keys.

Woods, D. L., Kishiyama, M. M., Yund, E. W., Herron, T. J., Edwards, B., Hink, R. F., & Reed, B. (2012). Improving digit span assessment. 33(1), 1–11. https://doi.org/10.1080/13803395.2010.493149.Improving
registration_responses.q17.question:
Main analyses

The primary aim of the statistical analyses will be to test the effect the labelling intervention and SEP on self-served energy. Secondary analyses will be run in order to investigate the role of potential mediators to explain the relationship SEP-self-served energy. The measure of SEP used in our main analyses will be the highest educational qualification (binary variable: lower vs. higher) because previous research showed that people of higher education were more likely to use nutrition labels (Breck et al., 2014; Cowburn & Stockley, 2008).

Linear mixed effect models will be run in order to test the effect of the labels and of highest educational qualification on the self-served energy, with participants and dishes set as random effects to account for correlation between repeated measures by the same participant and across the different food items. The main model will test the effect of the labelling intervention (four levels: kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling, no labelling), highest educational qualification (two levels: lower, higher) and the interaction between labelling intervention and highest educational qualification. If the interaction is significant, analyses will be stratified by highest educational qualification (lower and higher) and two linear mixed models will be fitted to examine the effect of the labelling intervention on self-served energy.

If there is a main effect of the labelling intervention in one of the above linear mixed models we will follow up this main effect by conducting the following pairwise comparisons:

-	Self-served energy in each of the three labelling conditions compared to no labelling condition:
o	No labelling vs. kcal labelling
o	No labelling vs. PACE labelling
o	No labelling vs. kcal and PACE labelling combined

-	Self-served energy in the combined labelling condition compared to single labelling conditions
o	Kcal and PACE labelling combined vs. kcal labelling
o	Kcal and PACE labelling combined vs. PACE labelling

-	Self-served energy in one single labelling condition compared to the other single labelling condition:
o	Kcal labelling vs. PACE labelling

We will apply a Bonferroni correction to the level of significance based on the number of pairwise comparisons made (e.g., 12 comparisons: 0.05/12=0.004).

Sensitivity analyses

We will conduct sensitivity analyses to examine whether the pattern of results from the main analyses differ when:

-	excluding the aim guessers from the main analyses, or if more than 20% of participants guess the aim of the study, including an ‘aim guessing’ variable (two levels: yes, no) as a covariate in the main model;

-	substituting highest educational qualification by level of education (composite score) in the main model;

-	including hunger and liking as covariates in the main model as these two variables are likely to influence how much one serves oneself of a dish;

-	excluding any dish that is familiar to less than 50% of participants or that is scored < 50 in liking on average (mid-way of the scale) to examine whether results are consistent when only well liked and familiar foods are used.

We will report whether sensitivity analyses result in deviations from the pattern of significance to the main analyses (i.e., any significant differences between conditions becoming not significant, and vice versa).

Secondary analyses

The main analyses will be repeated using alternative measures of SEP to investigate whether different measures lead to the same pattern of results. Highest educational qualification will be substituted by 1/ equivalised income, and 2/ SSS.

Moderated mediation analyses

We will report and compare the measures of inhibition, working memory, healthiness and weight control motivation in food choices overall and for participants of lower vs. higher education level using means, standard deviations and t-tests.

If the main analyses suggest that highest educational qualification moderates the effect of labelling intervention (i.e., the labelling intervention*highest educational qualification is significant), moderated mediation analyses will be performed in order to explain the different effect of labelling intervention in participants of lower vs. higher education level. We will test as mediators the measures of inhibition, working memory, healthiness and weight control motivation in food choices only if we find individual differences on these measures between participants of lower and higher education level. Moderated mediation analyses will examine the extent to which they mediate the effect of highest educational qualification on self-served energy in each labelling condition (kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling, no labelling).

The moderated mediation will be tested by estimating the conditional indirect effect of highest educational qualification through M for kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling, no labelling conditions and testing the conditional indirect effect for those conditions using bias-corrected bootstrap. We will use the PROCESS macro (Model 15) on SAS version 9.3 that provides asymmetric bias-corrected bootstrap confidence intervals for inference about the conditional indirect effects using 5,000 bootstrap samples (Hayes, 2012). Moderated mediation will be tested by determining whether or not the confidence interval for the difference between conditional indirect effects for kcal labelling, PACE labelling, kcal and PACE labelling versus no labelling contains zero.

Breck, A., Cantor, J., Martinez, O., & Elbel, B. (2014). Who reports noticing and using calorie information posted on fast food restaurant menus? Appetite, 81, 30–36. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.appet.2014.05.027
Cowburn, G., & Stockley, L. (2008). Consumer understanding and use of nutrition labelling: a systematic review. Public Health Nutrition, 8(01). https://doi.org/10.1079/phn2004666
Hayes, A. F. (2012). PROCESS: A versatile computational tool for observed variable mediation, moderation, and conditional process modeling (University).

attributes.title: Barriers to wearing personal protective equipment in response to COVID-19
attributes.description: The objective of the study is to understand the publics’ attitudes toward wearing face masks in response to COVID-19 given conflicting information in the media.

copyright_holders: H. Lauren Min and Julie L. Schiro

q2.value:
1. We predict a continuous by continuous interaction between the perceived social risk of wearing a facemask and the perceived threat of contracting COVID-19. 
a. At lower levels of perceived social risk, we predict a positive slope between perceived threat and likelihood of wearing a facemask.
b. As perceived social risk increases, this positive slope will flatten and become non-significant. 

2. As perceived social risk increases, dissonance (between perceived level of protection of facemasks and level required before willing to wear one) will increase. 

3. Informing people that the World Health Organization is reconsidering its current official recommendation regarding facemasks for the public will increase intentions to wear a facemask.

4. Perceived social risk and advice from authority (e.g., from the World Health Organization) will be more predictive of intentions to wear a facemask than perceived threat of contracting COVID-19, demographic variables, and political ideology.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (advice from public health authority) and 2 levels (official advice, reconsideration of official advice), and 5 within-subjects covariate measures (perceived efficacy, perceived threat, perceived social risk, demographics, political ideology).

q7.value: We will use block randomization, where each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the two experimental conditions.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific, an online data collection platform. Participants will be paid .40 pounds sterling for agreeing to participate. Participants must be at least 18 years old and reside in the United States.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 350 participants.

question.value:
We will manipulate advice from authority (two levels: official advice, reconsideration of official advice). All participants will be exposed to the following advice:

"The World Health Organization's (WHO) current advice for the public is to NOT wear a facemask if you are healthy." 

Only participants in the reconsideration of official advice condition will be exposed to the following additional information: 

"However, "the WHO is opening up its discussion again looking at the new evidence to see whether or not there should be a change in the way it's recommending facemasks should be used," said Professor Heymann, former director at the WHO."

1a. The key dependent variable is intention to wear a cloth facemask, which we assess with the following question: 
"How likely are you to wear a cloth facemask the next time you are in a public space (e.g., grocery shop), assuming that you have one in your possession?" (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'extremely unlikely', 7 being 'extremely likely').

1b. The second dependent variable addresses "facemask dissonance," which we define as the difference between the level of protection people think cloth facemasks provide, and the level of protection they would require before wearing one themselves. This will be computed by taking the difference in responses to the following two questions within-participant. 
(1) The level of protection that facemasks provide can be described with a number. For example, the the 'N95' designation means that when subjected to careful testing, the respirator blocks at least 95 percent of very small (0.3 micron) test particles. What do you think is the level of protection that cloth facemasks provide? (on a scale of 0-100).
(2) What level of protection would you require before you would be willing to wear a cloth facemask? (on a scale of 0-100).

2. We also have several other dependent measures that we are registering as exploratory:
a. "Would you be interested in learning more about how to make a simple homemade cloth facemask using common household supplies? If yes, we have a 30-second instructional video to share at the end of the survey" (yes or no, plus time spent watching the video).
b. "Would you like to see links to the most up-to-date information (we could find) on mask wearing from The World Health Organisation and the Center for Disease Control (CDC)? If so, you will see links to this information on the next page" (yes or no, plus how many links participants actually click). 

3. We will measure perceived social risk by asking participants the following 7 questions (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'strongly disagree', 7 being 'strongly agree').
a. I would feel ________ (socially awkward/uncomfortable/shamed) if I wore a cloth facemask the next time I am in a public space (e.g., grocery store).
b. I think that others would view me as ________ (foolish/smart/selfish/overdramatic) if I wore a cloth facemask the next time I am in a public space (e.g., grocery store). 

4. We will measure perceived threat of COVID-19 by asking participants the following 4 questions (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'strongly disagree', 7 being 'strongly agree').
a. I think that COVID-19 poses a substantial risk to my health.
b. I think that COVID-19 poses a substantial risk to the health of my loved ones.
c. I think that COVID-19 is just like the flu.
d. I think that COVID-19 is being blown out of proportion. 

5. We will measure perceived efficacy by asking participants, "How effective do you think that cloth facemasks are at protecting the mask wearer? (Assume the person wearing the mask is healthy)" (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'not at all effective', 7 being 'extremely effective'). 

6. We will measure political ideology by asking participants, "How would you describe your political ideology" (on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'left/liberal', 4 being 'moderate', 7 being 'right/conservative').

7. We will measure age, gender, and political ideology.

8. We will measure access to masks to analyze as a control variable by asking participants, "Do you have access to the following for personal use (check all that apply): cloth mask (purchased or gifted), cloth mask (homemade by you), N95 (medical-grade) mask, surgical mask."

1. We will take the mean of the 7 questions above to create a single measure of ‘perceived social risk.' (The question containing "smart" will first be reverse-coded). 
2. We will take the mean of the 4 questions above to create a single measure of ‘perceived threat' of COVID-19. (The questions containing "flu" and "blown out of proportion" will first be reverse-coded)

1. We predict a continuous by continuous interaction between the perceived social risk of wearing a facemask and the perceived threat of contracting COVID-19. 
a. At lower levels of perceived social risk, we predict a positive slope between perceived threat and likelihood of wearing a facemask.
b. As perceived social risk increases, this positive slope will flatten and become non-significant. 

Model Specification: intentions = b0 + b1 (perceived threat) + b2 (perceived social risk) + b3 (perceived threat*social risk)+ b4 (age) + b5 (gender) + b6 (political ideology) + b7 (perceived efficacy) + b8 (advice from authority)
 
We will follow up with simple effects tests where we center perceived threat and perceived social risk at each point on the scales (1 - 7). (Floodlight analysis)

2. As perceived social risk increases, dissonance (between perceived level of protection of facemasks and level required before willing to wear one) will increase. 

Model Specification: dissonance = b0 + b1 (perceived threat) + b2 (perceived social risk) + b3 (age) + b4 (gender) + b5 (political ideology) + b6 (advice from authority)

3. Informing people that the World Health Organization is reconsidering its current official recommendation regarding facemasks for the public will increase intentions to wear a facemask.

Model Specification: intentions = b0 + b1 (perceived threat) + b2 (perceived social risk) + b3 (age) + b4 (gender) + b5 (political ideology) + b6 (perceived efficacy) + b7 (advice from authority)

4. Perceived social risk and advice from authority (e.g., from the World Health Organization) will be more predictive of intentions to wear a facemask than perceived threat of contracting COVID-19, demographic variables, and political ideology. 

Model Specification: intentions = b0 + b1 (perceived threat) + b2 (perceived social risk) + b3 (age) + b4 (gender) + b5 (political ideology) + b6 (perceived efficacy) + b7 (advice from authority)

attributes.title: legal youth gambling April 2020
attributes.description:
The UK is unique in having allowed under 18s to legally engage in a number of gambling or “gambling-like” activities for a number of years. For example, national lottery products can be purchased from the age of 16, and some low-stakes slot machines (“category D fruit machines”) can be legally played at any age.

This is a retrospective study correlating recollected usage of these legal youth gambling products with current gambling problems in a group of UK adult gamblers. This study is relevant to the current landscape, where a number of gambling-like opportunities have recently become accessible to under 18s (e.g., “loot boxes” in video games), but not enough time has yet passed to see how these new products might contribute to later life gambling problems and harm.

The survey will not investigate illegal youth gambling, as from a regulatory standpoint this is more of a secondary enforcement issue.

q1.value: Philip Newall, Alex Russell, Lukasz Walasek

q2.value:
We predict there will be positive correlations between recollected usage of legal youth gambling and
adult problem gambling severity, as measured by the problem gambling severity index.
 
An alpha level of .01 will be used, adjusting the conventional .05 level for the fact that five main comparisons are being made.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a correlational survey. One element is the measurement of adult gambling problems, via the Problem Gambling Severity Index (Ferris & Wynn, 2001). The main novel aspect is the recollected legal usage of fivegambling products which are available to under 18s:
 
National lottery tickets -- a standard international lottery, legal to use from the age of 16
National lottery scratchcards -- standard instant scratchards, legal to use from the age of 16
Category D fruit machines -- electronic gambling machines with a maximum bet of 10p and a maximum payout of £5. Legal to use from any age.
Coin push machines -- arcade machines where coins of value up to 10p are wagered in the hope of winning more coins. Legal to use from any age.
Crane grab machines -- arcade machines costing up to £1 to play, where the aim is to successfully grab a prize worth up to £50. Legal to use from any age.

For each product, participants will be asked how frequently did they engag
e with these forms of gambling when they were below the age of 18. Responses will be given on a 5-point scale with the following labels: Never, Rarely, Occasionally, Frequently, Very frequently.

These gambling products vary by the age they can be used from and also the extent to which they resemble conventional gambling products. Each of these products will come with a short block of descriptive text and a picture, so that each question will be clear to participants. Descriptive text and images used will be uploaded to the study page’s OSF link.
 
The survey also contains a demographics block, which includes questions about gender, occupation, age, and education level.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We aim to collect 1,000 current UK nationals (who were also born in the UK) and who are adult gamblers. Participants will be collected via Prolific Academic, and Prolific’s pre-screeners used to ensure they satisfy the inclusion criteria. We will exclude any participant who tries to complete the survey twice. They will be paid £.50 for taking part, which should equate to more than £6/hour pro-rata. The study should be available on Prolific for no longer than a week.
 
Participants will additionally be pre-screened to be aged 40 or younger. This is because one of the gambling products, national lottery scratchcards, was only introduced in 1995. We want to ensure that all participants had an opportunity to legally use these products while being aged under 18. By removing participants aged over 40 we also reduce the extent to which memory biases might affect the results. We will give our participants an opportunity to share any comments with us at the end of the study. We will exclude data from anyone who will use this space to tell us that they encountered a technical issue during the study.

The main novel measured variable is recollected legal usage of that legal youth gambling product, measured on a 5-point Likert scale (see example below)
 
“How often do you recall using category D fruit machines while being under the age of 18?
Never
Rarely
Occasionally
Frequently
Very frequently”
 
Each of these questions will also contain descriptive text explaining what that gambling product is.
 
We decided to use frequency rather than expenditure, since expenditure may vary due to staking limits varying between the products, and the products potentially being appealing to people at different age ranges.
 
We will also collect the Problem Gambling Severity Index.

The goal of the analysis is to determine whether increased levels of engagement with legal youth gambling products is associated with adult gambling problems. This will be done for each of the five youth gambling products separately.
 
The dependent variable for each product is the Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI). PGSI is very likely to be positively skewed. Thus, we will run a test for skewness. Using Bulmer’s (1979) classic skewness descriptives, we will declare PGSI to be positively skewed if the relevant skewness statistic is > 1. If PGSI is positively skewed, we will use a log (+1) transformed version of the variable. If PGSI is not skewed, we will use raw scores. Using a log-transformed version of skewed dependent variables, particularly the PGSI, is relatively common in gambling and related literature (e.g., Browne et al., 2019).
 
The independent variables (frequency of engagement in each form) are coded as 0 = ‘never’, 1 = ‘rarely’, 2 = ‘occasionally’, 3 = ‘frequently’, 4 = ‘very frequently’. The response option of ‘never’ is qualitatively different to the other response options. Therefore, we will split the research question for each gambling product into two orthogonal (independent) aspects:
 
Is any level of engagement with a youth gambling product versus having never used that product associated with adult PGSI scores?
For gamblers who have used a given gambling product, are increased levels of recollected usage associated with adult PGSI scores?
 
A significance level of .01 will be used, since we are introducing a Bonferroni correction for the fact that five products are being tested. A further Bonferroni correction is not introduced for splitting the overall research question into aspects 1) and 2), as these are individual sub-components of the overall research question. Either the “never vs any frequency” or “frequency” components of the independent variables being statistically significant will support the hypothesis.
 
At this stage we as yet do not know how many participants will endorse having engaged in each of the five types of legal youth gambling. It is possible that almost all, or almost none, of participants will report engaging in a specific form. If a given gambling product was used by nearly everyone in the sample, then we will be unable to detect reliable estimates for aspect 1) above. If a given gambling product was used by almost nobody in the sample, then we will be unable to detect reliable estimates for both 1) and 2) above.
 
Therefore, we will not run analysis 1) for a given gambling product is used by .95 or more of the sample. We will not run either analysis 1) or 2) if a given gambling product is used by less than .05 of the sample.
 
The analysis will be performed via generalized linear models. A separate model will be used for each research question and for each product (10 models in total). 
References
 
Browne, M., Hing, N., Rockloff, M., Russell, A. M., Greer, N., Nicoll, F., & Smith, G. (2019). A multivariate evaluation of 25 proximal and distal risk-factors for gambling-related harm. Journal of Clinical Medicine, 8(4), 509.
Bulmer, M. G. (1979). Principles of statistics. Courier Corporation.

registration_responses.q2:
We predict there will be positive correlations between recollected usage of legal youth gambling and
adult problem gambling severity, as measured by the problem gambling severity index.
 
An alpha level of .01 will be used, adjusting the conventional .05 level for the fact that five main comparisons are being made.

q4: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q6.question:
This is a correlational survey. One element is the measurement of adult gambling problems, via the Problem Gambling Severity Index (Ferris & Wynn, 2001). The main novel aspect is the recollected legal usage of fivegambling products which are available to under 18s:
 
National lottery tickets -- a standard international lottery, legal to use from the age of 16
National lottery scratchcards -- standard instant scratchards, legal to use from the age of 16
Category D fruit machines -- electronic gambling machines with a maximum bet of 10p and a maximum payout of £5. Legal to use from any age.
Coin push machines -- arcade machines where coins of value up to 10p are wagered in the hope of winning more coins. Legal to use from any age.
Crane grab machines -- arcade machines costing up to £1 to play, where the aim is to successfully grab a prize worth up to £50. Legal to use from any age.

For each product, participants will be asked how frequently did they engag
e with these forms of gambling when they were below the age of 18. Responses will be given on a 5-point scale with the following labels: Never, Rarely, Occasionally, Frequently, Very frequently.

These gambling products vary by the age they can be used from and also the extent to which they resemble conventional gambling products. Each of these products will come with a short block of descriptive text and a picture, so that each question will be clear to participants. Descriptive text and images used will be uploaded to the study page’s OSF link.
 
The survey also contains a demographics block, which includes questions about gender, occupation, age, and education level.
registration_responses.q10.question:
We aim to collect 1,000 current UK nationals (who were also born in the UK) and who are adult gamblers. Participants will be collected via Prolific Academic, and Prolific’s pre-screeners used to ensure they satisfy the inclusion criteria. We will exclude any participant who tries to complete the survey twice. They will be paid £.50 for taking part, which should equate to more than £6/hour pro-rata. The study should be available on Prolific for no longer than a week.
 
Participants will additionally be pre-screened to be aged 40 or younger. This is because one of the gambling products, national lottery scratchcards, was only introduced in 1995. We want to ensure that all participants had an opportunity to legally use these products while being aged under 18. By removing participants aged over 40 we also reduce the extent to which memory biases might affect the results. We will give our participants an opportunity to share any comments with us at the end of the study. We will exclude data from anyone who will use this space to tell us that they encountered a technical issue during the study.
registration_responses.q15.question:
The main novel measured variable is recollected legal usage of that legal youth gambling product, measured on a 5-point Likert scale (see example below)
 
“How often do you recall using category D fruit machines while being under the age of 18?
Never
Rarely
Occasionally
Frequently
Very frequently”
 
Each of these questions will also contain descriptive text explaining what that gambling product is.
 
We decided to use frequency rather than expenditure, since expenditure may vary due to staking limits varying between the products, and the products potentially being appealing to people at different age ranges.
 
We will also collect the Problem Gambling Severity Index.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The goal of the analysis is to determine whether increased levels of engagement with legal youth gambling products is associated with adult gambling problems. This will be done for each of the five youth gambling products separately.
 
The dependent variable for each product is the Problem Gambling Severity Index (PGSI). PGSI is very likely to be positively skewed. Thus, we will run a test for skewness. Using Bulmer’s (1979) classic skewness descriptives, we will declare PGSI to be positively skewed if the relevant skewness statistic is > 1. If PGSI is positively skewed, we will use a log (+1) transformed version of the variable. If PGSI is not skewed, we will use raw scores. Using a log-transformed version of skewed dependent variables, particularly the PGSI, is relatively common in gambling and related literature (e.g., Browne et al., 2019).
 
The independent variables (frequency of engagement in each form) are coded as 0 = ‘never’, 1 = ‘rarely’, 2 = ‘occasionally’, 3 = ‘frequently’, 4 = ‘very frequently’. The response option of ‘never’ is qualitatively different to the other response options. Therefore, we will split the research question for each gambling product into two orthogonal (independent) aspects:
 
Is any level of engagement with a youth gambling product versus having never used that product associated with adult PGSI scores?
For gamblers who have used a given gambling product, are increased levels of recollected usage associated with adult PGSI scores?
 
A significance level of .01 will be used, since we are introducing a Bonferroni correction for the fact that five products are being tested. A further Bonferroni correction is not introduced for splitting the overall research question into aspects 1) and 2), as these are individual sub-components of the overall research question. Either the “never vs any frequency” or “frequency” components of the independent variables being statistically significant will support the hypothesis.
 
At this stage we as yet do not know how many participants will endorse having engaged in each of the five types of legal youth gambling. It is possible that almost all, or almost none, of participants will report engaging in a specific form. If a given gambling product was used by nearly everyone in the sample, then we will be unable to detect reliable estimates for aspect 1) above. If a given gambling product was used by almost nobody in the sample, then we will be unable to detect reliable estimates for both 1) and 2) above.
 
Therefore, we will not run analysis 1) for a given gambling product is used by .95 or more of the sample. We will not run either analysis 1) or 2) if a given gambling product is used by less than .05 of the sample.
 
The analysis will be performed via generalized linear models. A separate model will be used for each research question and for each product (10 models in total). 
References
 
Browne, M., Hing, N., Rockloff, M., Russell, A. M., Greer, N., Nicoll, F., & Smith, G. (2019). A multivariate evaluation of 25 proximal and distal risk-factors for gambling-related harm. Journal of Clinical Medicine, 8(4), 509.
Bulmer, M. G. (1979). Principles of statistics. Courier Corporation.

attributes.title: Evidence map of professional peer-to-peer interventions
attributes.description: We will establish an evidence map of empirical evaluations of peer-to-peer support interventions for working professionals. The evidence map is designed to provide an overview of the research area and will combine systematic searches and explicit eligibility criteria with a visual representation of the evidence base.

attributes.title: Examining the Association of Food Insecurity & Obesity Among American  Indian/Alaska Native Children
attributes.description: The proposed study will examine the association between food insecurity and obesity and the effect of Native language and culture on the association of food insecurity and obesity among AI/AN Head Start children ages 3- to 5-years old. Furthermore, this study seeks to explore gender differences in these relationships for AI/AN Head Start children.

q2.value:
Food insecurity is positively associated with obesity in 3- to 5-year-old AI/AN Head Start children.
AI/AN Head Start children’s experience of Native language and culture will be negatively associated with obesity.
AI/AN Head Start children's experience of Native language and culture will weaken the association between food insecurity and obesity.
AI/AN Head Start boys will have a higher rate of obesity than AI/AN Head Start girls, but the patterns of relationships among food insecurity, Native language and culture, and obesity will be the same across gender groups.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Secondary analysis of data from the 2015 American Indian and Alaska Native Family and Child Experiences Survey.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: Although the data have already been obtained by the study team, no analyses have been done that would reveal patterns among study variables.  The only analyses run by the study team thus far have been psychometric analyses to ensure scales are appropriately constructed.

question.value: Secondary data are being analyzed and thus does not include interaction with human subjects.  An IRB application has already been submitted to our home institution, and the project was provided exempt status under paragraph 4.

q11.value: Our study will include data from the 708 AI/AN children in the AI/AN FACES 2015 dataset.

question.value: Please see attached document, "Measures", for details on all variables.
Please see attached document for scale information.  Factor analysis will be completed for all scales.

Data analyses will be conducted using MPlus software. Based on prior analyses with the secondary data source, it is known that 10% of the data are missing. To address missing data, the use of weight analysis will be employed to adjust for sample attrition and reduce possible finding bias that is associated with missing data. Once missing data have been addressed, psychometric analyses will be conducted on the measures of food insecurity, Native language experiences, and culture experiences.  
	To address hypothesis one, regression analysis will be conducted to identify if higher scores on the food insecurity scale are associated with an increase in obesity among AI/AN Head Start children.  The independent variable, food insecurity (X) and outcome variable, obesity (Y) regression model will be written as: Y = iy + aX + ey, where i represents intercept and e represents error. The direct effect of X on Y can be estimated as a.  To address hypothesis two, the previous regression model will be expanded by adding Native language and culture variables. This expanded model will investigate the indirect effects of the predictor variable on the outcome variable via Native language experiences (M1) and culture experiences (M2). The expanded model will be written as:  M1= iM1 + a1X + eM1, M2= iM2 + a2X + eM2, Y = iy + c’X + b1M1 + b2M2 + ey. The indirect effects will be estimated as the product of four regression coefficients a1, a2, b1, and b2. To address hypothesis three, data will be disaggregated by gender groups and the aforementioned regression model will be conducted for each group to identify model differences between gender groups.

q21.value: To address missing data, the use of weight analysis will be employed to adjust for sample attrition and reduce possible finding bias that is associated with missing data.

AI/AN Head Start boys will have a higher rate of obesity than AI/AN Head Start girls, but the patterns of relationships among food insecurity, Native language and culture, and obesity will be the same across gender groups.

attributes.title: Systematic Review and Evaluation of Hoarding Measures
attributes.description: This project is a systematic review of self-report measures related to hoarding disorder. Measurement properties of each measure will be evaluated using COSMIN methodology.

q2.value: No specific hypotheses. The objective of the review is to identify all patient-reported assessment instruments specific to hoarding disorder and evaluate their measurement properties.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Systematic review and evaluation of measurement properties using COSMIN methodology.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Systematic literature searches will be conducted in PsycINFO, MEDLINE, Psychology and Behavioral Sciences Collection, and CINAHL Complete using the following search string: “hoarding disorder” OR “compulsive hoarding” AND (HR-PRO[tiab] OR HRPRO[tiab] OR HRQL[tiab] OR HRQoL[tiab] OR QL[tiab] OR QoL[tiab] OR quality of life[tw] OR life quality[tw] OR health index*[tiab] OR health indices[tiab] OR health profile*[tiab] OR health status[tw] OR ((patient[tiab] OR self[tiab] OR child[tiab] OR parent[tiab] OR carer[tiab] OR proxy[tiab]) AND ((report[tiab] OR reported[tiab] OR reporting[tiab]) OR (rated[tiab] OR rating[tiab] OR ratings[tiab]) OR based[tiab] OR (assessed[tiab] OR assessment[tiab] OR assessments[tiab]))) OR ((disability[tiab] OR function[tiab] OR functional[tiab] OR functions[tiab] OR subjective[tiab] OR utility[tiab] OR utilities[tiab] OR wellbeing[tiab] OR well being[tiab]) AND (index[tiab] OR indices[tiab] OR instrument[tiab] OR instruments[tiab] OR measure[tiab] OR measures[tiab] OR questionnaire[tiab] OR questionnaires[tiab] OR profile[tiab] OR profiles[tiab] OR scale[tiab] OR scales[tiab] OR score[tiab] OR scores[tiab] OR status[tiab] OR survey[tiab] OR surveys[tiab])))

From the articles found, duplicates will be removed and the remaining unique records will go through two screening phases. In the first stage, independent reviewers will read titles and abstracts to determine eligibility (i.e., each record will be assessed by two independent reviewers). Any disagreements will be resolved by discussion until a consensus is reached. In the second stage, independent reviewers will read full-text articles to further assess eligibility. Disagreements will be similarly resolved. The following criteria will be used:

Inclusion criteria
1. Full-text article
2. Published in peer-reviewed journal
3. Written in English
4. The measure or one of its subscales is designed to assess an outcome or process specific to hoarding disorder (e.g., hoarding severity; difficulty discarding, clutter, excessive acquisition; cognitive, behavioral, and emotional processes specific to hoarding; quality of life or impairment specifically related to hoarding)
5. The measure was developed or adapted for patient-report
6. No population restriction
7. The article reports results of a validation study (i.e., at least one explicit study aim is to validate the properties of this particular measure)

Exclusion criteria
1. Broader measures of OCD with no subscale for hoarding
2. Measures of constructs related but not specific to hoarding (e.g., anthropomorphism)
3. Measure items could not be located (after Internet searches, library requests, and contacting authors directly)
4. Measure was only used as an outcome measurement instrument (COSMIN recommendation from manual)
5. Measure was used in a validation study of another instrument (COSMIN recommendation from manual)

Psychometric and descriptive data from the included articles will be extracted by two independent reviewers. Discrepancies will be resolved by referring to the original article and conferring between reviewers until a consensus is reached.

q11.value: Sample size depends on the number of articles included in the review.

question.value: NA.

Internal consistency, reliability, measurement error, content validity, structural validity, hypotheses testing for construct validity, cross-cultural validity/measurement invariance, criterion validity, and responsiveness.

Methodological quality ratings will be based on a four-point scale: 0 = poor, 1 = fair, 2 = good, 3 = excellent. Psychometric quality ratings will be based on a categorical ratings: (+) sufficient, (?) indeterminate, (-) insufficient, (0) no information available.

Specific details on how these ratings are determined can be found here: https://www.cosmin.nl/wp-content/uploads/COSMIN-syst-review-for-PROMs-manual_version-1_feb-2018-1.pdf
No statistical analyses will be performed.

q21.value: Missing data will be indicated as such in reported findings; no data imputation will be done.
